title: I just had a game with an actual griefer.  I'm sorry.
body:
I'm **SO** sorry!

Our LB goes 0/2/5 in lane and our jg doesn't give her the second blue.  Then she:

- splitpushes minions to towers for the rest of the game
- takes multiple friendly RED buffs
- takes multiple scuttles from the rest of us when we had map control
- clears friendly jg camps during Dragon/Baron teamfights 
- never, ever wards. 

Never will I harass tryhards or Meals On Wheels botlanes in-game ever again.  Nothing is as bad as what that LB did, not even leaving or going AFK.  We won anyway, but if Yi wasn't on our team with two dragons at 12 minutes we would have lost that at 20 and it would be entirely that LB's fault.

Me too LOL but I wish for eveyone else not to have to deal with this in their own games, and wish upon a star that I never be like that LB either in-game or irl.

Despite being a team game, there’s a really weird and individualistic attitude a lot of people seem to have toward playing; basically, the same mindset as “when we lose it’s my team’s fault because I’m not a shit player” is present in “when I stop having fun, everyone else has to too”. I don’t think it’s just “human nature” or whatever, because environmental traits are a huge factor. If the game really discouraged behavior like that properly, it wouldn’t happen as frequently. I hate that I see it so often in the player base but I’m not sure what can be done about it

Because this game is completely selfish. It makes you resent your teammates as you compete for resources with them and their failures have disproportionate impact on you as this game unlike Heroes of The Storm for example has the concept of a fed lane.

In Heroes of The Storm, no matter how many tiems a bad Jaina (mage) dies to a Valeera in her lane (assassin), that Valeera will never become a raid boss for the rest of your team to face.

And what's more, as unskilled as the Jaina is, it won't be a snowball disadvantage as Heroes of The Storm passively gives you power spikes much more frequently so you are caught up to the opponent for much of the match or at worst at a slight disadvantage. It all comes down to how well you rotate, and how well you teamfight, not about amassing unsurpassable advantages against a lesser skilled foes and making the rest of your enemies pay for their deficient team mate.

This game:

1) Splits XP the more people in a lane.
2) Splits gold
3) Makes you resent kill stealers as a person KS'ing you is the difference between whether a roam is worth or not compared to AFK farming your waves since gold income is an active endeavor far more than a passive caught up mechanism.
4) It doesn't matter if a jungler finally ganked the top lane you were farming under turret 50 CS behind the opponent if you didn't get the kill, you're still in the same crap state, that's how much a difference an assist makes vs. a kill. Assists need to be more rewarding, or kills need to be brought down to the levels of assists in xp and gold payout.

If this game was much more diligent about passive catch up gold and XP to keep matches more even instead of total stomps, the game would be less wretched for most people.

Yes, in league with some champs you can 1v9, but the flip side to that is that bad players and trolls can drag you down far worse as well.

This is accurate, the game mechanics do promote individualism, but to what end is this point? It remains a team game, where the sum of the team is multiplied by how well they cooperate- that is, to build an effective strategy against the enemy and execute it.

I notice that players with a strong lead tend to try to push their lead, often times exposing themselves. The good ones just take advantage of mistakes (which happens all the time) while preparing for the next step to winning. I believe that the problem in that case is not that there is a raidboss, but that the team isn't doing what they need to win. That skilled player was doing a favor for the losing team in capitalizing on mistakes.

Inversely, having the unskilled player on your team is at worst a roadbump. Look at it this way; if you're skilled (of course!) then there is a 4/9 chance you'll have an unskilled player on your team, and a 5/9 chance the enemy will. So the presence of unskilled players at your rank is actually a slight statistical advantage. Rejoice!

I don’t think “just be skilled enough to work around massive enemy advantages” is a valuable contribution to this discussion. It’s at best a version of the meme that says “if I were faced with a disadvantage in game, I would simply, not be faced with it”. 

Individualism is an anti-social behavior. In League’s case it has the specific consequence of pitting you against your team even when you’re reliant on them to win, and it encourages you to blame your own shortcomings on that of your teammates and draw false conclusions on situations like whether enemy champions are overpowered, or your teammates were deliberately feeding. Saying the game should evolve to mitigate this aspect isn’t unproductive. League players have a specific reputation of being some of the most unbearable in the gaming world, and I don’t think that’s a mistake.

It's not "skilled enough", its "strategic enough". In other words, leadership. A valuable skill very, VERY few people exhibit in League, but would be very helpful toward winning. Thing is, nobody has authority, and many act like we need that for leadership. When splitting hair on how important it is to win, its on another level of play that probably won't happen in solo que much, but ultimately, if it doesn't happen in your games, whose fault is that?

Develop leadership skills.

My point is that it remains a team game, despite having some things that promote individualistic attitudes.

All the amount of leadership won't do crap if your guidance with pings for dragon or telling ADC's top group instead of staying in sidelanes afk farming with a 4 kill enemy shaco or LB around all falls on deaf ears.

Which often it does, because most people in this game have a win lane mentality.

We came off a game where they tried to early invade, I turned it around with panth stun and got the tristana mid early first blood and my bot lane another 2 kills.

Result? Tristana wins mid lane handily, but decides she will split push all game long when the enemy team has a nocturne+fiora in their comp and we lose the game since she throws all that lead trying to win the game on her own instead of taking those leads with her team and crushing teamfights (we won every single teamfight she actually was in, but that rarely happened and her selfishness cost us elder dragon after we had captured every previous dragon and turned the game around for the enemy team).

This game is filled with people who only care to win their lane and try to 1v9. It does not encourage teamplay whatsoever.

In Heroes of The Storm this would never happen because there is never a point where an enemy Vayne or Jax or Yi gets fed 12 kills by deficient players early and they can just 1v9. People in this game are spoiled by how snowball-prone laning outcomes are.

The equivalent of this happens in any team game. Someone plays the solo hotshot and won't listen to anybody.

My suggestion does not always work, but it does work. Can't win them all. Sometimes the cooperation is negative and the team ends up as less than the sum.

"If I were at a point of disadvantage where even top tier elo players would FF because they know it isn't winnable I would simply, develop leadership skills"

EDIT: For clarity, it should be obvious I'm not saying there aren't ways to work around existing disadvantages and win games. The fact that there exist ways to work around a flaw I'm critiquing doesn't change the nature of the flaw in my mind. I seek to be a leader to my team or encourage others to lead at every turn because I agree it's a valuable trait. This is still irrelevant to my overall point

EDIT2: I would also like to point out that downloading the onus of solving these flaws or critiques I’m making onto individual players by encouraging them to just develop leadership skills is on the same wavelength as “just be a better worker and you’ll lift yourself up by your bootstraps”. RIOT and other similarly profitable gaming giants can take responsibility for what they contribute to unhealthy dynamics, it’s really okay

"If suffering from individualistic factors, use leadership skills. This is the answer to your problem."

This is how it is relevant. I was also pointing out- yes, there are indeed things that go in that direction- but to what end is the point? What could Riot do outside of reworking the game? This is part of what makes League. I was pushing the conversation along. It does not end with "I have made a point."
Are you genuinely asking what addressing this problem would look like...? Because I assumed you were just being dismissive.

Yep, after all, I was offering a solution. Do you have a viable way to deal with it? I'd like to repeat that changing the fundamentals of League gameplay is not an option.

Edit: critism includes a "should have" or a way to fix it, after all! I know you said you didn't have an answer before.
